citations.narrative:
An adult wolf named Seeu, lacks a functional perimeter fence around its enclosure. The fence is located to the left of the
property and is less than 8ft in height. This side of the fence faces an open lot containing a home. The perimeter fence
adjacent to his enclosure has a row of brush on both of its sides, along with some trees. These vary in density offering the
wolf some privacy, but there is a break of visibility onto the next lot which may serve as a potential escape route for the
wolf.
A perimeter fence is required for wolves and serves to act as a secondary containment. It is meant to prevent their escape
from their primary enclosure and to keep any unwanted animals and unauthorized people out. The act of escaping by the
animal and entry of unwanted animals and people can pose injury and harm to them as well as to people living in the
vicinity.
The licensee must construct a perimeter fence that is 8 feet high for potentially dangerous animals, such as, but not
limited to, large felines (e.g., lions, tigers, leopards, cougars, etc.), wolves, coyotes, and foxes. For smaller felines (e.g.,
lynx, bobcat, servals etc.) a 6 feet high perimeter fence is required.
Correct by February 17, 2026.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
